Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2012 07:06PM Runnr wrote: Wow, I guess things have changed at Sloan Kettering.  I've been there twice for second opinions over the course of my treatments.  They wanted all original pathology, all medical records and scans.  It was tedious, but once they had the information there was no problem. I was last there 3 years ago. Since I'm already considered a patient there, I assume I can go back if I feel the need.   My onc welcomes second opinions, it's never been a problem. That's the way it should be.

Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2012 10:43AM Runnr wrote: My markers went way up so a Pet/Ct was ordered.  It showed what appeared to be lesions in liver.  For comfirmation a biopsy was performed and confirmed the liver mets.  I would want confirmation before changing treatment.  My liver function is normal. Definitely ask onc more about why he assumes liver mets.  Biopsy was no big deal for me.  Onc consulted with Interventional Radiologist to determine if biopsy was appropriate, they made the decision together.  IR has continued on my medical team and has performed several TACE (chemoembolization) procedures on my liver. Good luck!
Posts.Title: Liver....Please Read and Share your Thoughts lukejessesmom lilylady

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2009 10:57AM Runnr wrote: I was on Avastin for 18 months.  I got high blood pressure about 6 months into it.  I was put on blood pressure meds.  The meds had to be increased once to control the bp. It took about 6 months after coming off the Avastin for the bp to get back to normal.  The Avastin worked for me, so in my case it was worth it.  I may go back to Avastin later, if needed.  Hope this helps.

Posts.Content: Oct 9, 2012 05:53PM Runnr wrote: Great news Soleil!  We sound very similar.  My liver mets progressed on Abraxane, and again later on Afinitor. During the whole time the Xgeva kept my bone mets stable, and most recently improved! I just redid chemoembolization to one side of liver last week, and will do other side in another week or so. After I recover from second lobe, I will start Navelbine, which, hopefully will at least keep liver stable.  I'm looking at it as a maintenance chemo. So happy for you!
Posts.Title: I got Approved for SIRT!!!! soleil505 redwolf8812

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2013 04:55AM Runnr wrote: I went 10 years without a port and finally gave in this year when I had to go on Navelbine.  Navelbine is very irritating to the veins and can cause damage so the port was required.  I've never had problems with nurses accessing my veins.  I was just stubborn about not wanting a port. I asked for the smallest port I could get, it's a super slim power port and not very noticable.  I'm thin, live in FL wear lots of t-shirts and bathing suits.  I'm happy with my port and will keep it for as long as I need chemo of any type. Hope this helps.
Posts.Title: Is a port necessary? SandyinPa Blossoms

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2012 12:27PM Runnr wrote: I've been on Xanax and Lexapro for quite a while.  Low dose on each.  If I feel myself getting anxious I can take an extra Xanax.  I rarely do this.  Exercise helps alot.  Anything your doc will allow.  I do yoga on a regular basis.  I don't feel like a zombie at all.  Hope this helps.

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2012 10:54PM Runnr wrote: Following Pet/CT I had a totally seperate CT of liver only with and without contrast to determine the extent of lesions.  I think the techs also had special instructions for certain views the doc wanted. The scans were done within 3 weeks of each other.  I think it was ok with insurance because they were two different tests.  Not sure if this helps, but I thought I'd throw it out there.

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2012 02:07AM Runnr wrote: Jill, I had chemoembolization for multiple liver mets and I also have bone mets everywhere.  Insurance was no problem. (Medicare and Cigna) The chemoembolization followed by the Afinitor/Aromasin combo resulted in a huge drop in my markers, which are very accurate for me. Scans are scheduled for next month. My Interventional Radiologist told me that chemoembolization has been around in the US for a long time, techniques improving all the time.  You may want to check it out.
Posts.Title: Hmmmm...tears? JillThut CoolBreeze

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2012 06:23PM Runnr wrote: Just saw your post Soleil.  Glad you are through the worst and feeling better. I did pretty good.  I was given Zofran and Decadron in the hospital, stayed over night and went home next day. The worst side effects for me were flu like aches & pains, and of course pain in the liver area.  I was on Dilaudid for pain in the hospital and that was it.  I had the nurse load me up right before I went home.  Once home I had a script for dilaudid and zofran but didn't use either one.  Still took a week and a half before I felt good enough to go out. Just got cleared and scheduled for the second lobe this morning.  So next week I do it all over again on Tuesday.  I feel it is worth it.......  From there it's on to Navelbine.  Sending hugs your way
Posts.Title: I got Approved for SIRT!!!! soleil505 redwolf8812

Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2012 03:25PM Runnr wrote: Chick, we sound similar.  I have numerous liver mets and bones are stable.  In case insurance won't cover therasphere's, ask about chemoembolization.  It's routinely covered for BC to the liver.  I just finished one lobe, will do the other on Tues and then follow up with Navelbine for maintenance.   I did the chemoembolization once before, back in April, it worked beautifully, but the maintenance with Afinitor failed.  I am grateful for another chance at it with the Navelbine.   Good luck!
Posts.Title: I got Approved for SIRT!!!! soleil505 redwolf8812

Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2012 05:50PM Runnr wrote: I did the chemoembolization to both lobes of liver in October.  Liver has improved as of recent pet/ct.   Doing Navelbine now as systemic therapy.  Markers are dropping.  I soo want this to keep working. Good luck ladies

Posts.Title: Steph's stomach is in burning pain after chemo .. any one else? Travelingpants2

Posts.Content: Runnr wrote: Hi All, I'm curious if anyone has had Avastin twice and the second time be effective?  I've been treated for bone mets since April 06.  On and off with Xeloda and hormonals.  First two times, 6months each with Xeloda & Avastin for about 19 months. Got a year reprieve with Falsodex.  Recently I've been on low dose Xeloda for about 14 months, hormonals not working. New progression.  Onc is going to try adding back the Avastin to the Xeloda to see if it will help manage the mets better.    Since it was working when I quit last time we are hoping it will work again.  Anyone been through this?  We are going to try this before going to the big guns chemo.  Guess time will tell. Thanks for any info.  Best wishes to all, Claudia Original DX Dec 02, ER/PR+, Her- Dx 4/12/2006, IDC, Stage IV, Grade 3, 5/9 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Avastin - 2nd time around Runnr PJB

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2012 08:10AM Runnr wrote: Jill, I don't know where they draw the line on number of mets and giving the ok on chemobolization to liver.  But I can tell you I had at least 8-10 in each lobe and went through the procedures last month. Medicare paid and it wasn't all that bad.  Chemo went directly to liver, with beads.  After 2 weeks, the first lobe already showed shrinkage. Then second lobe was done.  Scans won't be done till early July, so I won't have any real news until then.  Just thought I'd pass this along.
Posts.Title: Hmmmm...tears? JillThut CoolBreeze

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2012 01:12PM Runnr wrote: Paula, your ski story is hilarious!  One time I did a face plant at the side of a slope, broke my goggles and scared myself silly!  Went out and bought a helmet that night, I've worn one ever since! I tried to insert a link to ebay, but can't figure out how......  So, go to ebay, search chemo hats, look for the ones that look like a hat/scarf all in one.  The vendor I used is CJ's Chemo Hats.  She has an online store with just her stuff you can scroll through.  Lot's to pick from
Posts.Title: Bald again CoolBreeze JillThut

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2013 09:46AM Runnr wrote: I also had Avastin/Xeloda combo.  2 years with Avastin, 3 on Xeloda.  It worked great for me.  I think Avastin is one of those drugs that is good for some and not for others.  SE from Avastin were runny nose, my voice changed and high blood pressure that required meds.  Xeloda SE were hand and foot syndrome.  And, of course the fatigue. Good luck, glad to hear you have a better team to work with.
Posts.Title: Avastin? Anyone been on it? Anko66 TXGigi

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2012 01:58PM Runnr wrote: Ann, sorry about the hair loss. When I am out in public I wear a wig.  I have 3 I like, 2 short and 1 long. My 2 favorites are by Raquel Welch.  My hairdresser styled them for me.  The most I paid for the RW was $125.  The one I like the least is the expensive one. After searching all over for reasonably priced scarves I ended up buying them on ebay.  A former cancer patient makes them and sells them in lots of colors and patterns.  I bought 4, over time. They range from $14 - $18 each (more for silk). They are cotton and are made like a cap with elastic and ends that tie in the back, so they look like a scarf.  They stay on and are comfortable.  I wear them at home.   Hope this helps
Posts.Title: Bald again CoolBreeze JillThut
